messages.user_message: What is the appropriate nozzle temperature for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate nozzle temperature for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA) is generally in the range of 190–230°C. However, several studies suggest that the best properties for PLA prints are achieved at a temperature of 215°C. It is important to note that the optimum printing temperature can be affected by factors such as bed temperature, surrounding temperature, printing speed, and the plastic's crystallinity and thermal properties. Additionally, increasing the nozzle temperature to 240°C can make PLA 3D-printed parts more durable, but temperatures above this can lead to polymer degradation [reference_188.pdf, page 784; reference_120.pdf, page 290].

messages.user_message: What is the appropriate printing speed for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate printing speed for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA) is generally around 90 mm/s. This speed has been found to give the highest Young's modulus for pure PLA, indicating good mechanical properties. While there is a slight difference in Young's modulus between lower speeds (70 mm/s and 80 mm/s) and higher speeds (100 mm/s and 110 mm/s), 90 mm/s is commonly used for optimal results [reference_120.pdf, page 284].

messages.user_message: What is the appropriate layer height for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate layer height for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA) can vary depending on the desired surface quality and printing time. According to a study, the layer height was varied from 0.05 mm to 0.25 mm. The results showed that a smaller layer height of 0.05 mm resulted in the smallest surface roughness, while a larger layer height of 0.25 mm resulted in a rougher surface. Additionally, the printing time is inversely proportional to surface roughness, meaning that smaller layer heights will increase printing time [reference_145.pdf, page 2].
